docs.lead_paragraph: Hoping to learn more about how inactivity affects disease risk, researchers at the University of Missouri recently persuaded a group of healthy, active young adults to stop moving around so much. Scientists have known for some time that sedentary people are at increased risk of developing heart disease and Type 2 diabetes. But they haven't fully understood why, in part because studying the effects of sedentary behavior isn't easy. People who are inactive may also be obese, eat poorly or face other lifestyle or metabolic issues that make it impossible to tease out the specific role that inactivity, on its own, plays in ill health. So, to combat the problem, researchers lately have embraced a novel approach to studying the effects of inactivity. They've imposed the condition on people who otherwise would be out happily exercising and moving about, in some cases by sentencing them to bed rest.

headline.main: Phys Ed: To Avoid the Pitfalls of Inactivity, Just Walk Away

docs.abstract: Researchers at the University of Missouri imposed a regime of limited physical activity on a group of active adults in order to study the effect that a sedentary lifestyle has on blood sugar levels; study found that blood sugar spiked to unusually high levels after eating, even though participants' diets remained the same; results were published in journal Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise. Photo (M)/

docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE VOICE The battle rounds begin as the coaches enlist the help of music industry professionals as advisers. Christina Aguilera (above right) partners with Jewel and Lionel Richie, Adam Levine with Alanis Morissette and Robin Thicke, Cee Lo Green with Kenny Edmonds (a k a Babyface) and Ne-Yo, and Blake Shelton with Kelly Clarkson and Miranda Lambert. The coaches will then pit members of their own teams against one another in dueling duets before choosing the strongest vocalists to advance to the live shows. Carson Daly hosts. In ''Smash,'' at 10, Karen (Katharine McPhee) puts her acting talents to use at a government party. The drama between Michael (Will Chase) and Julia (Debra Messing) reaches a fever pitch as Eileen (Anjelica Huston) and Tom's assistant, Ellis (Jaime Cepero), form an alliance. 5:55 A.M. (Showtime) VIDAL SASSOON: THE MOVIE (2011) Craig Teper chronicles the life and times of Mr. Sassoon, whose wash-and-wear philosophy changed the world of hairstyling. (Above, models with Sassoon haircuts.) An ''extravagant verbal fusillade introduces a screen biography that sometimes feels like an infomercial,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. ''But in the documentary's defense, its upbeat tone, perky visual rhythm and sleek graphics capture the 'swinging '60s' aesthetic epitomized by Mr. Sassoon's major invention: the geometric 'five-point' haircut.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Many of the business world’s titans stay in shape at Sitaras Fitness, a Midtown Manhattan gym that is the brainchild of a bodybuilder. He — and his software — track the members’ progress.

headline.seo: Sitaras Fitness, Where Business Titans Work Out
headline.main: Trying to Feel Like a Million Bucks, Too
headline.print_headline: Trying to Feel Like a Million Bucks, Too

docs.abstract: Many of the business world’s titans of business and finance stay in shape at Sitaras Fitness, a Midtown Manhattan gym that is the brainchild of bodybuilder John Sitaras; he and his software track the progress of gym's 140-plus members; his proprietary personal training program separates his center from other high-end clubs.
